SO2 in the sintering flue gas severely inhibits the CO oxidation performance of commercial Pt/Al2O3 catalysts. However, the major poisoning mechanism of SO2 on Pt/Al2O3 in CO oxidation in the presence of H2O remains to be elucidated. Here, Pt/Al2O3 was pretreated with different reducing atmospheres at high temperatures. Among these, the catalyst pretreated with a CO atmosphere at 600 °C (denoted as Pt/Al2O3-CO-600) exhibited superior CO oxidation performance and enhanced sulfur resistance in the presence of both H2O and SO2. The combination of XPS, HAADF-STEM, TG-MS, SO2 oxidation test, and in-situ DRIFTS reveal that the Pt species on Pt/Al2O3-CO-600 transformed from Pt oxide clusters to metallic Pt nanoparticles. This transformation enhanced SO2 adsorption and reactivity, leading to increased sulfate accumulation. Despite the high SO2 reactivity and sulfate content, in-situ DRIFTS revealed that the CO reaction of Pt/Al2O3-CO-600 was less hindered by SO2 and the sulfated Al2O3. This is attributed to the high ratio of the under-coordinated (UC) Pt sites in Pt/Al2O3-CO-600, which promotes the reaction intermediates spillover from Pt site to Al2O3 compared to the Pt/Al2O3. This phenomenon was positively correlated with the sulfur resistance of reduced catalysts. Accordingly, the UC site contributes to the spillover of sulfate intermediate (H2SO4), reducing the CO reactivity loss of Pt/Al2O3 due to the intermediate coverage. This study elucidates that the primary poisoning pathway of Pt/Al2O3 in the presence of H2O and SO2 is the difficulty of sulfate intermediate spillover. Graphical Abstract Keywords Pt/Al2O3 SO2 poisoning CO oxidation Sulfur spillover Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Fossil fuels serve as a major energy source in modern industry. In the iron and steel industry, fossil fuel combustion generates complex exhaust gases, posing significant challenges for developing effective purification catalysts. Among these emissions, sintering process exhaust contributes approximately half of total emissions, containing CO, NOx, ppm-level SO2, and 10–20 vol% H2O [1,2]. Catalytic purification of CO and NOx must be conducted under harsh conditions with H2O and SO2 present. While extensive research has focused on NOx purification under SO2 and H2O exposure [3–7], CO oxidation catalysis has received comparatively less attention. Achieving efficient CO purification below 250 °C in the presence of H2O and SO2 remains a challenge [8–13]. Noble metal catalysts, particularly Pt and Pd, are widely used for CO oxidation due to their high activity and relative tolerance to H2O [14]. However, SO2 and its derivatives are the primary cause of catalyst deactivation. It is widely accepted that CO and SO2 competitively adsorb on noble metal site, leading to performance degradation [10,11,13,15]. Furthermore, SO3 migrates from noble metal site to the support, forming thermally stable sulfate species (decomposition temperature >500 °C), which further suppress catalytic activity [16,17].Under practical conditions, H2O reacts with SO3 to form H2SO4, which accumulates on the catalyst surface, causing severe deactivation [8,18]. Taira and co-workers[8] discovered different pore distributions of TiO2 support loaded with Pt can lead to distinct stability of CO oxidation under SO2 and H2O. They proposed the H2SO4 pore blockage hypothesis and elaborated that H2SO4 hinders reactant diffusion at 250–270 °C, due to the high boiling point of H2SO4 (300 °C). Therefore, the surface reactions of SO2, sulfite, sulfate, and H2SO4 under practical conditions collectively suppress the CO oxidation activity. Among noble metal catalysts, Pt/Al2O3 is the most extensively studied and commercially utilized system [18–21], featuring well-defined active site [22]. This catalyst system serves as an excellent model for investigating sulfur poisoning mechanisms. Theoretically, the formation of PtSO4 is unlikely due to its low thermodynamic stability [23–25]. Moreover, Al2O3 exhibits higher SO2 adsorption capacity through Al2(SO4)3 formation compared to TiO2 and SiO2 [26,27]. Nevertheless, Pt/Al2O3 exhibits poor performance for CO oxidation in SO2-containing atmospheres, indicating the existence of additional SO2 sensitivity factors. Identifying the dominant SO2 deactivation mechanism in Pt/Al2O3 could facilitate the design of sulfur-resistant Pt catalysts. To elucidate the dominant SO2 inhibition mechanism in Pt/Al2O3, precise control of Pt properties is essential. Similar to CO, SO2 adsorption and reactivity are strongly influenced by redox state of Pt [24], particle size [25], and local coordination environment [28,29]. Reductive pretreatments (H2 or CO) can induce Pt aggregation [30], thereby modifying Pt chemical state and particle size. The reduction conditions (temperature and gas composition) further influence Pt coordination [31–33], with CO reduction reported to promote the formation of under-coordinated (UC) Pt site [34]. Thus, controlled reduction condition provides an effective approach for tuning Pt properties. In this paper, a series of Pt/Al2O3 catalysts with varying particle sizes and coordinated states were prepared through controlled reduction under different temperatures and atmospheres. The results show that the reduced state of Pt nanoparticle exhibit enhanced the CO and SO2 oxidation reactivity. After reduction treatments, Pt/Al2O3 showed improved sulfur resistance at 200 °C in the presence of 50 ppm SO2 and 10 vol% H2O. Notably, CO reduction at 600 °C (Pt/Al2O3-CO-600) significantly improved both catalytic performance and SO2 tolerance. Contrary to conventional understanding [8–10,17,35,36], the increased stability of Pt/Al2O3-CO-600 was accompanied by increased sulfate accumulation, indicating that H2SO4 blockage—rather than sulfate formation or SO2 adsorption—represents the primary deactivation mechanism. Characterization and experimental results revealed that the UC Pt sites exhibit stronger CO adsorption compared with well-coordinated Pt sites, which promotes competitive displacement of SO3/H2SO4. The H2SO4 spillover is significantly promoted, thus regenerating the Pt sites for CO oxidation. Consequently, the UC sites dramatically improve the long-term stability of CO oxidation of Pt/Al2O3 in the presence of H2O and SO2. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation Pt/Al2O3 catalysts were prepared using Pt (NO3)2 as the precursor via the incipient wetness impregnation method. In the typical preparation, the corresponding quantity of the precursor solution, Pt (NO3)2 (5 wt% Pt), was added to Al2O3 support (obtained from Aladdin), and the mixture was then subjected to ultrasonic treatment for 30 min. Then, the sample was dried at 80 °C overnight, the solid was calcined at 500 °C for 4 h in static air, given 1 wt% Pt/Al2O3 catalyst. To reduce the Boudouard reaction effect, the samples were treated with 1 % CO or H2 as the reducing gas at a rate of 5 °C min−1 to the target temperature for 1 h. The catalysts were designated as Pt/Al2O3-x-y, where x represents the gas and y denotes the temperature. The catalysts were treated with CO or H2 at temperatures of 300 or 600 °C. 2.2 CO oxidation test The catalytic oxidation of CO and stability test were evaluated by diluting 100 mg (40–60 mesh) of catalyst in 200 mg of inert quartz sand (40–60 mesh) in a fixed-bed quartz reactor (diameter: 6 mm) at atmospheric pressure. The reaction conditions were as follows: 1 % CO, 10 % O2, 10 vol% H2O (when used), 50 ppm SO2 (when used), and N2 as the equilibrium gases, with a total flow rate of 100 mL min−1. This equates to a weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) of 60000 mL gcat −1 h−1. The stability test was performed at 200 °C under the same conditions as the activity test. Water vapor was introduced via bubbling, and its concentration was regulated by controlling the temperature of the bubbler (10 vol% at 50 °C). To prevent condensation of the water vapor, the temperature from the bubbler to the air inlet was maintained at 80 °C by a heated band. The concentration of CO was determined by methanation on a GC 2060 gas chromatograph and detected by an FID detector. The CO conversion ratio was calculated as： (1) X CO = C CO in − C CO out C CO in × 100 % X CO represents the CO conversion rate, while C COin and C COout denote the CO inlet and outlet concentrations, respectively. 2.3 Characterization Inductively Coupled Plasma Optical Emission Spectrometer (ICP-OES) was used to determine the Pt loading in the catalysts. X-ray diffraction (XRD) spectra were examined on a Bruker AXS D8 Focus diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (40 kV and 40 mA). The scanning range of 2θ was from 10° to 80°. Scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) characterization was performed on a ThermoFisher Talos F200X (FETEM, 200 kV). High-angle annular dark field (HAADF) STEM images were recorded using a convergence half-angle of 11 mrad, inner and outer collection angles of 59 and 200 mrad, respectively. Energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) was performed using four in-column Super-X detectors. The specific surface area of the samples was measured on a Micromeritics ASAP 2400 instrument at 77 K and calculated by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra were measured on a Thermo NECSA G2 instrument equipped with a hemispherical electron energy analyzer. X-ray excitation source: monochromatic Al Ka (hv =1486.6 eV), with the carbonaceous C 1 s peak (284.8 eV) as a reference to calibrate the binding energy. An in-situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (in-situ RIFTS) experiment was performed on a Nicolet Nexus 6700 FT-IR spectrometer (windowed for CaF2), with 64 scans collected at a resolution of 4 cm−1. Prior to measurement, samples were pretreated in Ar (50 mL·min−1) at 200 °C for 1 h to clean the surface. Background spectra were collected at target temperatures (50 °C and 150 °C). Reaction gases (matching stability test conditions) were introduced at 50 °C for 1 h, followed by heating to 150 °C for spectral recording. The temperatures (50, 150 °C) are T10, and T90 for the CO oxidation activity of Pt/Al2O3 in an atmosphere containing SO2 and H2O. Carbon monoxide temperature-programmed reduction (CO-TPR) and carbon monoxide pulse (CO-Pulse) were tested on a Micromeritics Model Auto Chem II 2920. For CO-TPR, catalysts (50 mg, 40–60 mesh) were pretreated in He (40 mL·min−1) at 200 °C for 1 h, cooled to 25 °C, and then heated to 700 °C at 10 °C·min−1 under 1 % CO/He (40 mL·min−1). CO2, CO, H2O, and H2 signals were monitored by mass spectrometry. For CO pulse experiments, samples (20 mg, 40–60 mesh) were pre-reduced in 3 % H2/Ar (40 mL·min−1) at 200 °C for 30 min, purged in He (40 mL·min−1), and cooled to 25 °C. Pt dispersion was calculated from the particle size (D pt)： (2) D pt = 1.07 Dispersion % Hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was performed on a PX200 instrument with a TCD detector. Catalysts (50 mg, 40–60 mesh) were pretreated in Ar (50 mL·min−1) at 300 °C, cooled to 25 °C, and then heated to 700 °C at 10 °C·min−1 under 5 % H2/N2 (50 mL·min−1). The Thermogravimetric-Mass spectrometry (TG-MS) was conducted on a PerkinElmer Pyris 1 TGA. Samples (10 mg) were dehydrated in Ar (30 mL·min−1) at 50 °C, then heated to 800 °C at 10 °C·min−1. Mass signals for CO2 (m/z = 44), SO2 (m/z = 64), and H2O (m/z = 18) were recorded. The temperature-programmed desorption of NH3 (NH3-TPD) was conducted on a PX200 apparatus with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The catalyst (50 mg) was pretreated in Ar (50 mL/min−1) at 400 °C. Then cooled down to 90 °C, the catalyst was treated in a flow of NH3 (50 mL/min−1) for 40 min, and then exposed to Ar (50 mL/min−1) for 1 h to remove physically absorbed NH3. Finally, the sample was heated from 90 to 700 °C at 10 °C/min−1 in Ar flow (50 mL∙min−1). The amount of desorbed NH3 was determined by a TCD. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 CO oxidation performance Pt/Al2O3 catalysts were synthesized via incipient wetness impregnation (IWI). The as-prepared samples were subjected to reduction pretreatment under 1 % H2/N2 or CO/N2 at target temperatures (300 or 600 °C) for 1 h. The catalytic performance of Pt/Al2O3 and reduced Pt/Al2O3-x-y (x = H2, CO; y = 300, 600) was evaluated in CO oxidation under both dry and wet conditions ( Figs. 1a and 1b). Under dry conditions, the pretreated catalysts exhibited better catalytic activity than untreated Pt/Al2O3 (T100 = 158 °C). Specifically, Pt/Al2O3-CO-600 (T100 = 147 °C) showed the highest activity, followed by Pt/Al2O3-CO-300 (T100 = 154 °C), Pt/Al2O3-H2-600 (T100 = 155 °C), and Pt/Al2O3-H2-300 (T100 = 154 °C). This trend became more pronounced under wet conditions, where the CO-reduced catalysts demonstrated remarkable activity (Pt/Al2O3-CO-600: 116 °C; Pt/Al2O3-CO-300: 117 °C) compared to both H2-reduced samples (Pt/Al2O3-H2-600: 121 °C; Pt/Al2O3-H2-300: 130 °C) and the untreated catalyst (142 °C). Overall, the reduced catalysts showed comparable activity in dry condition, whereas the CO-reduced samples exhibited significantly enhanced performance in the presence of H2O compared to those reduced in H2. This improvement may be attributed to the formation of a higher density of under-coordinated Pt sites induced by CO treatment[37,38]. However, significant differences emerged in their CO oxidation stability when tested in the presence of H2O and SO2. In the stability test of CO oxidation reaction at 200 °C, 10 vol% H2O and 50 ppm SO2, as shown in Fig. 1c, the untreated Pt/Al2O3 maintained > 90 % conversion for 3 h, the pretreated catalysts showed dramatically improved stability: Pt/Al2O3-CO-600 (30 h) > Pt/Al2O3-CO-300 (20 h) > Pt/Al2O3-H2-300 (19 h) > Pt/Al2O3-H2-600 (18 h). Notably, Pt/Al2O3-CO-600 maintained 98 % conversion throughout the 30-h test period, representing a tenfold stability improvement for the untreated catalyst. The slower deactivation rates of the pretreated catalysts, even when conversion dropped below 100 %, further confirm their enhanced robustness. To further exclude the potential impact of the activity factor, a comparative test was conducted on the activity and stability of Pt/Al2O3-H2-200 (Figure S1). While its activity (T100= 156 °C dry, 132 °C wet) fell between untreated and CO-600-treated catalysts, its stability resembled the untreated sample. This decoupling of activity and stability strongly suggests that the exceptional performance of high-temperature reduced catalysts stems from structural modifications rather than higher initial activity. 3.2 Effect of high-temperature reduction treatment on the structure of Pt/Al2O3 The structural characteristics of the catalysts were systematically investigated to elucidate the effects of reduction conditions. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis revealed that both Pt/Al2O3 and reduced Pt/Al2O3 catalysts maintained the characteristic γ-Al2O3 crystal structure (JCPDF No. 29–0063), as shown in Fig. 2a. The absence of discernible Pt diffraction peaks suggests the presence of highly dispersed Pt species. Nitrogen adsorption-desorption measurements (Table S1, Figure S2) confirmed that the textural properties of the support, including BET surface area (144 ± 3 m2/g), average pore diameter (6.1 ± 0.2 nm), and pore volume (0.22 ± 0.01 cm3/g), remained essentially unchanged following reduction treatments. Pore size and pore distribution changes due to high temperatures were excluded [8].The acid quantity changes shown by NH3-TPD (Figure S3) are not significantly correlated with its sulfur stability. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis provided insights into the electronic states of Pt species (Fig. 2b). The Pt 4d5/2 binding energy (BE) at 317.0 eV for untreated Pt/Al2O3 corresponds to oxidized Ptn+ species[39,40]. After reduction pretreatment, the BE shifted to lower values (314.7–314.9 eV), characteristic of metallic Pt0 [39,41,42].Pt 4 f spectra confirm this conclusion (Figure S4)[43,44]. This transformation was further corroborated by hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) profiles (Figure S5), which exhibited three distinct reduction features: overlapping peaks at 107 and 197 °C (assigned to Pt-O-Pt species reduction) and a well-defined peak at 376 °C (attributed to Pt-O-Al species associated with penta-coordinated Al3+ sites) [22,45,46]. Complete reduction to metallic Pt was achieved at 300 °C, while treatment at 600 °C led to Pt particle agglomeration, as evidenced by decreasing Pt dispersion (96 %, 82 %, and 71 % for Pt/Al2O3, Pt/Al2O3-H2-300, and Pt/Al2O3-H2-600, respectively), determined by CO pulse chemisorption (Table S1). The influence of CO pretreatment was examined through CO temperature-programmed reduction (CO-TPR) experiments (Fig. 2c). Untreated Pt/Al2O3 displayed two prominent peaks at 120 °C (Pt-O reduction) and 320 °C (water-gas shift reaction involving Al-OH groups), as confirmed by simultaneous mass spectrometry detection of H2 and H2O (Figure S6) [47]. Notably, for the Pt/Al2O3-CO catalysts, which underwent ex-situ CO pretreatment, the Pt-O reduction features appeared at lower temperatures (Pt/Al2O3-CO-300: 70 and Pt/Al2O3-CO-600: 122 °C), while the Al-OH-related peak remained at 316 °C. This shift in the Pt-O reduction peaks is attributed to the ex-situ CO pretreatment, which modifies the Pt-O species prior to the TPR measurement. The unchanged position of the Al-OH peak demonstrates that CO pretreatment selectively alters the Pt-O species without significantly affecting the hydroxyl groups on the alumina support, thus the change of support property was less relation with the performance of catalyst during stability test. CO adsorption diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (CO-DRIFTS) provided detailed information about the coordination environment of Pt sites (Fig. 2d). The CO adsorption bands at both top (from 2100 to 2000 cm−1) and bridged adsorption (∼ 1830 cm−1) sites, which are the typical characteristics of Pt [48–50]. Four distinct vibrational bands at 2100–2000 cm−1 were observed at 2098 cm−1 (CO on Ptn+), 2080 cm−1 (well-coordinated Pt0, WC, coordination number (CN) = 8–9), 2060 cm−1 (under-coordinated Pt0, UC, CN = 6–7), and 2040 cm−1 (highly under-coordinated Pt0, HUC, CN = 4–5) [37,38,48,51,52]. The spectrum revealed that CO-pretreated catalysts exhibited higher proportions of UC and HUC sites compared to H2-reduced counterparts. The catalytic stability followed the trend: Pt/Al2O3-CO-600 > Pt/Al2O3-CO-300 > Pt/Al2O3-H2, with stability directly correlating with the abundance of under-coordinated sites. This restructuring phenomenon, driven by CO chemisorption-induced surface energy minimization [32,34,37,53,54], generates catalytically favorable under-coordinated Pt sites (UC and HUC) that enhance both O2 dissociation and CO adsorption capacity [37,55]. High-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) elucidated the morphological evolution of Pt species (Figs. 2e, 2f). The untreated Pt/Al2O3 catalyst exhibited predominantly sub-nanometer Pt clusters (<1 nm) that served as the primary active site [22,45]. Upon CO pretreatment at 600 °C, these initially dispersed Pt clusters underwent significant restructuring to form pyramid-like Pt nanoparticles (∼1.5 nm) with abundant step and kink sites [34,54,56]. In summary, comprehensive characterization using XPS, TPR, CO-DRIFTS, and HAADF-STEM demonstrates that reduction pretreatment primarily modifies the electronic state and coordination environment of Pt species. CO pretreatment induces reconstruction of well-coordinated Pt sites into under-coordinated configurations, with the HUC/UC ratio serving as a key determinant of catalytic stability. 3.3 Effect of under-coordinated Pt on CO oxidation in the presence of H2O and SO2 To investigate changes induced by the UC Pt sites in the stability test, the Pt valence and the accumulation of sulfate were examined in the used catalyst by XPS and Thermogravimetric-Mass spectrometry (TG-MS). The XPS analysis was conducted on the used catalysts (after a 20-hour test). The Pt 4d spectra ( Fig. 3a) revealed that the Pt 4d5/2 BE of the used catalysts ranged from 315.8 to 314.7 eV (Pt/Al2O3-used, Pt/Al2O3-CO-300-used, Pt/Al2O3-CO-600-used), which is consistent with metallic Pt0 [39,57]. A comparison between the fresh Pt/Al2O3 catalyst (Fig. 2b) and the used catalyst (Fig. 3a) indicated that any potential redox effect of Pt during CO oxidation had not significantly change the stability test results. Furthermore, the platinum valence of all used catalysts was in the metallic state, which confirms that PtSO4 was not formed on the used catalysts. The S 2p XPS spectra (Fig. 3b) provided further insights. The red lines in the figure correspond to the S 2p spectra of the fresh catalysts. S 2p3/2 BE of used catalysts centered at 169.2–169.5 eV, attributed to sulfate on Al sites [9,10,15]. A semi-quantitative comparison of surface sulfur content, expressed as S/Al atomic ratios, showed that the used Pt/Al2O3-CO-300 (S/Al = 0.072) and Pt/Al2O3-CO-600 (S/Al = 0.089) exhibited higher sulfur content than the used Pt/Al2O3 (S/Al = 0.055). This suggests that SO4 2- accumulation was more pronounced on Pt/Al2O3-CO catalysts than on Pt/Al2O3 after the stability test, implying that SO4 2- is not the primary poison affecting CO oxidation on Pt/Al2O3. To further explore the accumulation and decomposition behavior of SO4 2- on the used catalysts, TG-MS analysis was conducted under argon (Ar) conditions. The weight loss (TG) and derivative thermogravimetric (DTG) curves of the used samples (Figs. 3c and 3d) were compared with those of fresh samples (Figure S7). Based on the mass signals (Figures S8-S10), weight loss in the 50–500 °C range was attributed to water desorption and carbonate decomposition, while weight loss in the 550–800 °C range was ascribed to SO4 2- decomposition. Compared to Al2O3-used, the weight loss of Pt/Al2O3-used and Pt/Al2O3-CO-600-used showed a significant increase above 500 °C (Fig. 3c), indicating that the presence of Pt led to substantial SO4 2- accumulation, with Pt serving as the primary SO2 active sites. The DTG curve of Pt/Al2O3-CO-600-used (Fig. 3d) showed an increased peak intensity and a forward shift in peak temperature above 500 °C, which suggests the formation of new species. The SO2 (m/z = 64) mass spectral signal (Fig. 3e) revealed that Pt/Al2O3-CO-600-used displayed two distinct SO2 peaks at 550 °C (surface sulfate) and 800 °C (bulk sulfate) [24,25], indicating altered sulfate precursor migration compared to Pt/Al2O3. Notably, both decomposition temperatures were significantly higher than the test temperature, confirming the stability of sulfate during the performance test. This finding effectively rules out sulfate decomposition as a primary poisoning mechanism. The altered migration of sulfate precursors in Pt/Al2O3-CO-600 likely also affects the migration and deposition of carbonate intermediates in the CO oxidation reaction. To verify this hypothesis, the CO2 (m/z = 44) mass spectral signal was analyzed (Fig. 3f). The highest CO2 signal was observed on Al2O3-used (peak at 420 °C), consistent with its limited deep oxidation capacity. For Pt/Al2O3-used, three CO2 peaks were observed at 130, 246, and 361 °C, while Pt/Al2O3-CO-600-used exhibited peaks at 154, 355, and 550 °C, indicating a change in intermediate migration. Notably, despite its enhanced redox activity, which promotes sulfate accumulation and SO2 oxidation (verified by SO2 oxidation test, as shown in Figures S11 and S12), Pt/Al2O3-CO-600 demonstrated exceptional SO2 tolerance. This observation contradicts the conventional hypothesis that sulfate accumulation and SO2 oxidation performance degrade SO2 tolerance [9,10,15,17]. Instead, the high mobility of H2SO4, as proposed in the literature[8], may explain this phenomenon. When H2SO4 is the primary poison, its mobility enhances SO2 resistance rather than sulfate accumulation and SO2 oxidation performance. Consequently, the restructured sulfate precursor migration in Pt/Al2O3-CO-600 likely underpins its superior SO2 tolerance. To validate this hypothesis, the in-situ DRIFTS experiments ( Fig. 4) provided further insights. Prior to in-situ testing, the CO reaction pathways on the surfaces of Pt/Al2O3 and Pt/Al2O3-CO-600 catalysts were investigated (Figure S13). After CO adsorption, O2 was introduced to analyze the CO adsorption peaks, revealing that the main CO adsorption peaks of both catalysts exhibited blue shifts (Pt/Al2O3 from 2059 cm−1 to 2066 cm−1, Pt/Al2O3-CO-600 from 2057 cm−1 to 2063 cm−1). This result indicates that CO and oxygen co-adsorb on the Pt surface, and the surface reaction of CO primarily follows the L-H mechanism[58,59]. The in-situ DRIFTS test process began at 50°C in a CO + O2 + H2O environment to stabilize the initial spectrum, followed by the introduction of SO2. For Pt/Al2O3 (Fig. 4a), sulfate species (1100–1300 cm−1) [20,21,24]were observed after 60 min, with sulfite (980–960 cm−1) on Al sites being the dominant sulfur species [20,60,61]. In contrast, Pt/Al2O3-CO-600 (Fig. 4b) exhibited a rapid increase in sulfate signal intensity, indicating enhanced SO2 reactivity, while Pt/Al2O3-CO-300 (Figure S14) displayed similar behavior. At 150 °C (Fig. 4c), the sulfate signals on Pt/Al2O3 intensified, accompanied by rising formate (1591 cm−1) [62,63] accumulation and declining bicarbonate (1650 cm−1) [63,64] and the and hydroxyl (3600–3300 cm−1) signals [65,66], suggesting that SO2 intermediates disrupted the equilibrium of CO oxidation intermediates. Pt/Al2O3-CO-600 (Figure 4d and S12) maintained stable or increasing CO oxidation intermediates and hydroxyl signals, indicating that sulfate did not significantly inhibit intermediate migration, and Pt/Al2O3-CO-300 (Figure S15) exhibited analogous behavior, with minimal disruption to CO oxidation intermediates. These results demonstrate that both Pt/Al2O3-CO-600 and Pt/Al2O3-CO-300 can rapidly spillover surface species from Pt sites, maintaining CO oxidation performance even when Al2O3 is sulfated, thus exhibiting high SO2 tolerance. Additionally, the stability of Pt-CO (2060 cm−1) on UC Pt sites during the in-situ DRIFTS test (Fig. 4) suggests that CO adsorption at UC sites is unaffected by SO2. CO may competitively displace SO2 or its intermediates on UC sites, contributing to the regeneration of UC sites for CO oxidation. This indicates a positive correlation between UC sites and SO2 tolerance in reduced catalysts (Pt/Al2O3-H2 and Pt/Al2O3-CO). To further test this hypothesis, CO oxidation stability tests were conducted under dry conditions in the presence of SO2 ( Fig. 5). Pt/Al2O3-CO-600 maintained 100 % conversion for 220 min, three times longer than Pt/Al2O3 (60 min). After conversion decreased, Pt/Al2O3-CO-600 stabilized at 58 %, significantly higher than Pt/Al2O3 (18 %). In addition, the CO conversion of Pt/Al2O3-H2-600 begun to decline at 100 min and stabilized around 25 %, falling between that of Pt/Al2O3-CO-600 and Pt/Al2O3. This further confirms that the strong adsorption of CO by under-coordinated Pt sites promotes competitive adsorption between CO and SO2, thereby enhancing the catalyst’s sulfur tolerance under dry gas conditions. This implies that SO3 spillover from Pt sites to Al2O3 is more efficient in Pt/Al2O3-CO-600, likely due to the strong CO adsorption at HUC and UC sites compared to well-coordinated (WC) sites [29,34,37,51].This facilitates competitive CO adsorption, enhancing SO3 spillover on HUC or UC sites. Thus, the strong CO adsorption at UC sites is a key factor promoting sulfate precursor (H2SO4 or SO3) spillover in reduced Pt/Al2O3 catalysts, as illustrated schematically in Fig. 6. 4 Conclusions This study investigated the influence of Pt redox state and coordination environment on SO2 tolerance in Pt/Al2O3 catalysts, revealing a novel mechanism for enhanced sulfur resistance. CO pretreatment generated Pt/Al2O3-CO-600 with a high proportion of under-coordinated metallic Pt sites, which exhibited improved SO2 tolerance during CO oxidation in the presence of SO2 and H2O. Characterization results indicated that under-coordinated sites possess stronger CO adsorption affinity compared to well-coordinated sites, enabling competitive displacement of SO3 or H2SO4 intermediates by CO. This property enhanced H2SO4 spillover from Pt to Al2O3 in Pt/Al2O3-CO-600, contributing to the regeneration of active Pt sites for sustained CO oxidation. Despite strong SO2 reactivity and high sulfate accumulation, the CO-pretreated catalysts exhibited significantly improved stability, confirming that H2SO4 mobility is crucial for SO2 tolerance in the presence of H2O. The findings highlight the importance of the Pt coordination environment in H2SO4 spillover, offering a potential direction for designing more sulfur-tolerant platinum-based catalysts. This work provides a foundation for further exploration of sulfur resistance mechanisms in catalytic systems. coredata.dc:description: SO2 in the sintering flue gas severely inhibits the CO oxidation performance of commercial Pt/Al2O3 catalysts. However, the major poisoning mechanism of SO2 on Pt/Al2O3 in CO oxidation in the presence of H2O remains to be elucidated. Here, Pt/Al2O3 was pretreated with different reducing atmospheres at high temperatures. Among these, the catalyst pretreated with a CO atmosphere at 600 °C (denoted as Pt/Al2O3-CO-600) exhibited superior CO oxidation performance and enhanced sulfur resistance in the presence of both H2O and SO2. The combination of XPS, HAADF-STEM, TG-MS, SO2 oxidation test, and in-situ DRIFTS reveal that the Pt species on Pt/Al2O3-CO-600 transformed from Pt oxide clusters to metallic Pt nanoparticles. This transformation enhanced SO2 adsorption and reactivity, leading to increased sulfate accumulation. Despite the high SO2 reactivity and sulfate content, in-situ DRIFTS revealed that the CO reaction of Pt/Al2O3-CO-600 was less hindered by SO2 and the sulfated Al2O3. This is attributed to the high ratio of the under-coordinated (UC) Pt sites in Pt/Al2O3-CO-600, which promotes the reaction intermediates spillover from Pt site to Al2O3 compared to the Pt/Al2O3. This phenomenon was positively correlated with the sulfur resistance of reduced catalysts. Accordingly, the UC site contributes to the spillover of sulfate intermediate (H2SO4), reducing the CO reactivity loss of Pt/Al2O3 due to the intermediate coverage. This study elucidates that the primary poisoning pathway of Pt/Al2O3 in the presence of H2O and SO2 is the difficulty of sulfate intermediate spillover.

coredata.dc:title: Mitigating SO2 poisoning during CO oxidation over Pt/Al2O3 catalysts via sulfur spillover from highly under-coordinated platinum to the Al2O3 support
